choices.text: Annual new case detection rate per lac
Proportion of newly diagnosed patients with grade-2 disability

questions.text: A public health official is evaluating the effectiveness of a health system in emphasizing early detection of leprosy in a community setting. Which of the following metrics would be most indicative of the system's commitment to early identification?" [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Proportion of newly diagnosed patients with grade-2 disability

 

  • The proportion of newly diagnosed patients with grade 2 disability is useful in determining whether the health system is giving importance to identifying leprosy in the community.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Treatment completion rate: This measures the effectiveness of treatment adherence and success but does not directly reflect the system's ability to detect cases early.

 

Option B. Annual new case detection rate per lac: While it shows the number of new cases detected, it doesn't indicate how early these cases are being detected.

 

Option C. Treatment initiation rate: This measures how quickly diagnosed patients begin treatment but does not indicate how early the cases are being detected.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The proportion of newly diagnosed patients with grade-2 disability is a key indicator of the effectiveness of a health system in detecting leprosy early.
  • Lower proportions suggest better early detection efforts

questions.text: A 60-year-old man who recently lost his wife complains that his intestines have rotted. He believes he is to blame for his wife's death and should be imprisoned. He complains that he is constantly depressed and has lost interest in daily activities since his wife's death. What is the most likely cause? (NEET PG  2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Psychotic depression

 

The patient's presentation of severe depressive symptoms (constant depression, anhedonia) combined with delusional beliefs (thinking his intestines have rotted, feeling culpable for his wife's death) is characteristic of psychotic depression. Psychotic depression, or major depressive disorder with psychotic features, is a subtype of major depression characterized by the presence of mood-congruent or mood-incongruent delusions or hallucinations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal grief reaction might involve feelings of sadness and even guilt, but it wouldn't typically involve delusions although transient hallucinations can be seen.

 

Option C. Delusional disorder involves holding one or more delusions in the absence of other psychiatric disorders. These individuals' functioning might not be notably impaired, and the delusions do not typically center around depressive themes.

 

Option D. Schizophrenia involves characteristic symptoms like hallucinations, delusions, disorganized speech or behavior, and negative symptoms. While depression can be a feature, the given presentation is more aligned with psychotic depression than with schizophrenia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Psychotic depression is seen in moderate to severe depressive disorder where the individual experiences both depressive symptoms and psychosis, such as delusions or hallucinations. These psychotic symptoms could be mood congruent (i.e, content of delusion/ hallucination is consistent with the depressed mood) or mood incongruent. Delusions in psychotic depression often revolve around themes of guilt, worthlessness, or illness.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 356, 360.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient undergoes a pacemaker replacement procedure at a tertiary care hospital. The surgeon successfully replaces the pacemaker and hands over the used device to the nursing staff for proper disposal as per biomedical waste management guidelines. According to the guidelines for biomedical waste management, in which colored bag should the used pacemaker be discarded? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Blue

 

  • According to biomedical waste management guidelines, used pacemakers, which are considered metal waste, should be disposed of in blue-colored containers or cardboard boxes marked with blue.
  • This ensures that the device is appropriately handled, disinfected, and sent for recycling or other safe disposal methods.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Left Gluteus minimus and Gluteus medius
Right Gluteus minimus and Gluteus medius

questions.text: A patient was asked to stand on his left leg and his right hip falls down, which among the following muscles will be affected in this case? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Left Gluteus minimus and Gluteus medius

 

Left gluteus minimus and gluteus medius muscles will be affected in this case.

 

The left gluteus minimus and gluteus medius muscles (supplied by the left superior gluteal nerve) are primarily responsible for abduction and stabilization of the hip joint, especially when standing on one leg.

 

Weakness or dysfunction in these muscles on the left side could lead to a drop in the right hip when the patient tries to stand on the left leg. This is because the left hip abductors are unable to maintain proper alignment and stability of the pelvis (Positive Trendelenburg's sign)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Gluteus Maximus: The gluteus maximus is primarily responsible for hip extension and external rotation but has a lesser role in hip abduction. Weakness or dysfunction of the gluteus maximus may not be the primary cause of the right hip dropping in this specific scenario.

 

Option C. Right Gluteus Minimus and Gluteus Medius: The right gluteus minimus and gluteus medius muscles on the same side as the falling hip are less likely to be the primary cause of the right hip dropping when standing on the left leg. These muscles would typically work to elevate and stabilize the right hip..

 

Option D.  Quadriceps: The quadriceps muscles are located in the front of the thigh and primarily function to extend the knee. While they play a role in maintaining knee stability during activities like standing, they are not the primary muscles responsible for stabilizing the hip during single-leg stance. Therefore, weakness in the quadriceps may not directly cause the right hip to drop.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Weakness in the left gluteus minimus and medius is indicated by the positive Trendelenburg's sign, where the pelvis drops on the side of the non-weight bearing leg (right), due to inadequate stabilization by these muscles on the standing leg (left).

questions.text:
Which of the following statements accurately describe the operation and management of Mobile Medical Units (MMUs)? [INICET MAY 2021]

 

  1. MMUs are run by the government
  2. MMUs are run by external agencies with medical supplies given by the government.
  3. MMUs are run by the government and medical supplies are also given by the government.
  4. MMUs are run by external agencies and medical supplies are also given by the external agency.
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 1, 2, and 3

 

  • MMUs can be operated by either the Government or an external agency; however, the availability of drugs and medical supplies is exclusively the responsibility of the Government.
  • Mobile Medical Units (MMU) represents a significant project within NRHM, aimed at delivering a variety of healthcare services to individuals residing in distant, hard-to-reach, unserved, and underserved regions, encompassing both rural and urban locations.
  • The goal is to bring essential healthcare services directly to the residents in these areas.

 

There are 3 models of operationalizing MMUs:

 

  1. Government operated MMU
  2. MMU operation is outsourced to an external agency, while the government covers capital expenses, medication, and supplies.
  3. External agency outsourcing includes both capital and operational expenses for MMUs.

 

The government is responsible for providing medication and supplies. MMUs offer essential primary healthcare services for prevalent illnesses (both communicable and non-communicable), reproductive and child health (RCH) services, screening examinations, and necessary referrals to advanced facilities and specialists. Medical Officer-led clinical services are delivered by a team, while mobilization and outreach activities are undertaken by ANMs and ASHA personnel.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Services and Resources of MMUs:

 

  • MMUs offer a variety of services, including primary care for common diseases, reproductive and child health services, diagnostic screenings, and referrals to specialized care.
  • They are equipped with facilities for basic diagnostic tests such as blood glucose monitoring, pregnancy testing, and sputum sample collection, among others.
  • Human resources typically include a medical officer, a nurse, a lab technician, a pharmacist/administrative assistant, and a driver/support staff.

questions.text: A patient presents with progressive vision loss. Imaging reveals an aneurysm compressing the optic chiasm. Which artery is most likely responsible for this compression? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Anterior communicating artery

 

  • The likely cause of vision loss in this patient is an aneurysm of the anterior communicating artery, which is situated in close proximity to the optic chiasma.
  • The Circle of Willis, a major arterial connection between the internal carotid and vertebrobasilar systems, lies within the subarachnoid space surrounding the optic chiasma and infundibulum.
  • In cases of an anterior communicating artery aneurysm, which connects the right and left anterior cerebral arteries and is positioned anterior and superior to the optic chiasma, the aneurysm may protrude posteriorly and compress the optic chiasma from above.
  • This can result in bitemporal hemianopia, or loss of vision in the left/temporal halves of both visual fields, as the nasal fibers of each retina cross through the chiasma at this level and may be affected.
  • Therefore, it is likely that the aneurysm is causing damage to the optic chiasma and resulting in the patient's vision loss.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anterior choroidal artery: This artery arises from the internal carotid artery and supplies parts of the hippocampus, lateral geniculate body, posterior limb of the internal capsule, and the choroid plexus of the lateral and third ventricles.

 

  • Relation to Optic Chiasma: It doesn't have a direct relationship with the optic chiasma, so an aneurysm here is less likely to cause vision disturbances related to chiasmal compression.

 

Option C. Middle cerebral artery (MCA): It is one of the three major paired arteries that supply the brain's cerebrum. It arises from the internal carotid artery and supplies a significant portion of the lateral convexity of the cerebral hemisphere.

 

  • Relation to Optic Chiasma: The MCA is located laterally and doesn't directly overlie the optic chiasma. Thus, an aneurysm of the MCA typically would not impinge upon the optic chiasma.

 

Option D. Anterior cerebral artery (ACA): It is one of the major paired arteries that supplies the brain's cerebrum. It arises from the internal carotid artery and supplies the medial and superior parts of the cerebral hemisphere.

 

  • Relation to Optic Chiasma: The ACA runs superiorly to the optic chiasma, similar to the anterior communicating artery. However, the anterior communicating artery, given its position and course, is more commonly associated with aneurysms that affect the optic chiasma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anterior communicating artery connects the two anterior cerebral arteries and is a part of the Circle of Willis, a circulatory anastomosis that supplies the brain.

 

Relation to Optic Chiasma: The anterior communicating artery runs superiorly to the optic chiasma. An aneurysm of this artery can impinge upon or compress the optic chiasma leading to visual disturbances, especially a particular kind of vision loss called bitemporal hemianopsia.

questions.text: A public health official is reviewing district data to determine which areas should be prioritized for tuberculosis (TB) interventions. According to the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP), which of the following HIV-TB prevalence rates would categorize a district as high-priority? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) >10%

 

  • According to the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP), districts are categorized based on specific criteria to prioritize TB interventions.
  • One of these criteria is the prevalence of HIV-TB co-infection.
  • High HIV-TB Prevalence: A district is categorized as high-priority if more than 10% of TB patients tested are known to be HIV positive.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: One basic health worker per 10,000 population
Responsibility of PHCs in malaria eradication

questions.text: The Chadah committee suggested all of the following options except: [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) One PHC for 50,000 population 

 

  • The correct answer, "B. One PHC for 50,000 populations," refers to a recommendation actually made by the Kartar Singh Committee, not the Chadah Committee. 
  • The Chadah Committee was established to assess the necessary arrangements for the Maintenance Phase of the National Malaria Eradication Program (NMEP). 
  • It emphasized integrating vigilance operations of the NMEP within general health services, specifically through PHCs at the block level, and allocating health workers specifically for malaria vigilance, among other public health tasks.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: As per the Factories Act of 1948, what is the maximum permissible weekly working hours, inclusive of overtime? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 60 hours

 

The Factories Act of 1948 permits a maximum of 48 hours of regular work per week, which can be extended up to 60 hours per week with standard overtime.

 

Factories Act – established in 1948:

 

  • Established to include all the factories except Defence, Mining, Railways and Eateries.
  • Per capita space: more than 500/ft3
  • One Safety officer for more than 1000 workers.
  • Children between 14-18 years can be employed only in certain industries and work only between 6 AM-7PM. They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours per day.
  • The maximum working hours for adults should be less than 48 hours per week or less than 9 hours per day.
  • With overtime being included, it should not be more than 60 hours per week.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maximum work hours per week is 48 hours. With overtime one can extend it upto 60 hours.

questions.text: Longitudinal growth of a long bone is most likely affected by a fracture involving which of the following regions? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Epiphyseal plate


The epiphyseal plate, also known as the growth plate, is a layer of hyaline cartilage located between the epiphysis (end) and the metaphysis of a long bone. This plate is crucial for the longitudinal growth of bones during childhood and adolescence. Active cell division occurs here, which contributes to the lengthening of the bone. Any damage or fracture at the epiphyseal plate can disrupt this growth process, leading to potential growth abnormalities.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epiphysis: The epiphysis is the rounded end of the long bone but is not directly responsible for bone growth. Fractures here do not significantly impact the longitudinal growth of the bone.

 

Option B. Metaphysis: The metaphysis is the flared part of the bone between the diaphysis and the epiphyseal plate. Although it plays a role in supporting growth, fractures here do not directly disrupt the longitudinal growth as much as a fracture at the epiphyseal plate would.

 

Option C. Diaphysis: The diaphysis is the shaft or central part of the long bone. Fractures in the diaphysis typically affect the strength and integrity of the bone but do not interfere with growth lengthwise.

 

Educational Objective:


The epiphyseal plate is crucial for the longitudinal growth of bones, and fractures here can significantly impact this process.

questions.text: During which phase of cardiac cycle is the first heart sound produced? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Isovolumetric contraction

 

Isovolumetric contraction is the phase during which the first heart sound (S1) is produced. This sound is primarily due to the closure of the mitral and tricuspid valves at the start of ventricular contraction, which prevents the backflow of blood into the atria and generates a sound marking the beginning of systole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rapid ejection phase: Incorrect because this phase follows the isovolumetric contraction and involves the ejection of blood into the aorta and pulmonary trunk as the ventricles contract further and the pressure exceeds that of the arteries. The valves are already open, and no significant sound is produced akin to S1 during this phase.

 

Option C. Slow ejection phase: Incorrect as this phase represents the tail end of the ejection process where the remaining blood is pushed out of the ventricles at a slower rate due to decreasing pressure gradients. Like the rapid ejection phase, it does not involve the opening or closing of valves that would produce a distinct heart sound.

 

Option D. Isovolumetric relaxation: Incorrect because this phase involves the relaxation of the ventricles without any change in volume, marked by the closure of the aortic and pulmonary valves, which produces the second heart sound (S2), not the first

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phases of cardiac cycle -

 

  • Cardiac cycle in ventricles last for 0.8 sec
  • Ventricular Systole - 0.3 sec.  – consist of 3 phases.
  • Ventricular Diastole - 0,5 sec - consist of 5 phases.

 

Phases of ventricular Systole -

 

1st Phase - Starts with closure of Mitral valve, which produces S1 sound. This phase is called as Isovolumetric contraction, it ends by opening of aortic valve.

 

2nd Phase - Phase of Rapid ejection - 2/3rd of the stroke volume is ejected.

 

3rd Phase - Phase of Slow ejection phase: Approximately 1/3rd of the remaining stroke volume is ejected

 

Phases of ventricular Diastole -

 

1st phase (Protodiastole) – which occurs just before the beginning of diastole (last for 0.04 Sec.)

 

2nd Phase - starts with closure of aortic valve, which produces S2 sound which is taken as- beginning of diastole proper. This phase is known as Isovolumetric relaxation.

 

Volume - constant, pressure – decrease

 

3rd Phase - Early Rapid filling phase and 4th Slow filling phase (passive filling of 2/3rd of blood)

 

* S3 sound produce due to rapid filling phase. Normally Can not be heard except few Hyperdynamic condition like: exercise, Pregnancy

 

4. Active filling phase (Remaining 1/3rd of filling due to atrial contraction)

questions.text: Which one of the provided thermometers is employed for measuring low air velocity as opposed to the cooling potency of the air? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Kata thermometer 

 

Kata thermometer is used to measure low air velocity rather than the cooling power of the air. It works by measuring the temperature difference between two thin wires heated to different temperatures in a moving air stream. The faster the air moves, the greater the temperature difference between the two wires, allowing the Kata thermometer to measure air velocity.

 

Other Options

Option B. Globe Thermometer: Measures mean radiant temperature, which is the average temperature of all the surfaces surrounding a particular point. This is useful in assessing thermal comfort in environments.

 

Option C. Wet Globe Thermometer: Used to measure heat stress by taking into account temperature, humidity, wind speed, and solar radiation. It is commonly used in the Wet Bulb Globe Temperature (WBGT) index.

Option D. Dial Thermometer: Measures air temperature using a dial indicator. It is a general-purpose thermometer and not specifically designed for measuring air velocity.


Educational Objective:

choices.text: Anterior wall of the left ventricle
Inferior surface of the right ventricle

questions.text: A patient with a recent MI underwent coronary angiography, which revealed a block in the anterior interventricular artery. The infarction is likely to be present in which of the following regions of the heart? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anterior wall of the left ventricle

 

Explanation:

 

The patient with recent myocardial infarction (MI), who underwent coronary angiography, revealed a block in the anterior interventricular artery (also known as the left anterior descending artery or LAD).

 

The LAD is a branch of the left coronary artery and is commonly referred to as the "widow's artery" due to its high incidence of involvement in angina and MI. The LAD runs along the anterior side of the heart and supplies the apex of the ventricle. The left coronary artery is the main artery supplying the left ventricle. Therefore, a block in the LAD would most likely result in an infarction in the anterior wall of the left ventricle.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior part of interventricular septum: Incorrect. The posterior part of the interventricular septum is primarily supplied by the posterior descending artery (PDA), which is usually a branch of the right coronary artery (RCA) or sometimes the left circumflex artery (LCX).

 

Option C. Lateral part of the heart: Incorrect. The lateral part of the heart is mainly supplied by the left circumflex artery (LCX), another branch of the left coronary artery.

 

Option D. Inferior surface of the right ventricle: Incorrect. The inferior surface of the right ventricle is supplied by the right coronary artery (RCA) and its branches, such as the marginal branch and the posterior descending artery (PDA).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anterior interventricular artery (LAD) supplies the anterior wall of the left ventricle, and a block in this artery can lead to an infarction in this region of the heart.

questions.text: In the below question mechanical receptors are given with their functions. Choose the correctly matched pair.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pacinian corpuscle - Fast Vibration

 

Pacinian corpuscles are specialized nerve endings located deep within the skin and other tissues. They are highly sensitive to high-frequency vibrations, making them particularly adept at detecting fast vibrations. These receptors are crucial for perceiving textures and fine details through vibration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ruffini - Fine touch: This is incorrect because Ruffini endings are mechanoreceptors that detect skin stretch, not fine touch. They are deeper in the skin and contribute to the sensation of skin deformation, which is associated with stretch rather than fine touch.

 

Option C. Meissner - Stretch: This is incorrect because Meissner's corpuscles are responsible for detecting light touch, not stretch. They are located near the surface of the skin and are sensitive to changes in texture and slow vibrations.

 

Option D. Merkel - Slow vibration: This is incorrect because Merkel cells are associated with fine touch and two-point discrimination, not slow vibrations. They are particularly sensitive to edges, points, and textures, which aids in tasks like reading Braille.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pacinian corpuscles are responsible for detecting fast vibrations, and Ruffini endings detect skin stretch.

questions.text: A person often feels that his hands are contaminated and he is forced to wash his hands. Recently, he feels this repetitive, distressing thought of repetitive hand washing has begun affecting his performance. Which of the following is the best treatment option for this patient? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Exposure and response prevention

 

The patient's symptoms are consistent with Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD). One of the most effective treatments for OCD is Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP), which is a type of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) specific for OCD.

 

Exposure and response prevention is the mainstay treatment for OCD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DBT (Dialectical Behavior Therapy): DBT is primarily used for borderline personality disorder and other self-harming behaviors.

 

Option C. Systematic desensitization: Systematic desensitization is a behavioral technique mainly used to treat phobias by gradually exposing the patient to the phobic stimulus.

 

Option D. CBT (Cognitive Behavioral Therapy): CBT is a broader therapeutic technique and is used in a variety of psychiatric disorders.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

For OCD, Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP), a specialized form of CBT, is the evidence-based first-line treatment. It involves exposing patients to their obsessional triggers while refraining from performing their compulsive rituals, gradually reducing the distress elicited by obsessions.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 425.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl has intense food cravings. She consumes a large amount of food, followed by self-induced vomiting. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bulimia nervosa

 

The patient's behavior of consuming excessive amounts of food (binge eating) followed by self-induced vomiting (a purging behavior) is characteristic of Bulimia nervosa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anorexia nervosa typically involves restriction of food intake leading to significantly low body weight and a fear of gaining weight. Binge eating and purging can also occur in anorexia nervosa, and this question should have ideally provided more information; with the imited information provided, bulimia nervosa is a better answer as it is characterised by binging and purging.

 

Option C. Atypical depression is a subtype of major depression and is not characterized by binge eating and purging, although increased appetite is seen.

 

Option D. Binge eating disorder involves episodes of overeating but without the regular purging behaviors seen in Bulimia nervosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bulimia nervosa is an eating disorder characterized by episodes of binge eating followed by inappropriate behaviors such as self-induced vomiting (purging) or hypergymnasia to prevent weight gain. It is usually associated with fear of gaining weight. Purging can lead to dental caries, knuckle callouses, parotitis, hypokalemic and hypochloremic alkalosis and rarely gastric or esophageal tear. Weight is usually normal, which differentiates from anorexia nervosa. Treatment includes CBT and SSRIs.

 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 469

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman was involved in a car accident two months ago, and she now complains of screaming and waking up in the middle of the night after having nightmares about the same incident over and over. Which of the following conditions does she have? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Post traumatic stress disorder

 

This woman's presentation of recurrent nightmares about a traumatic event (the car accident) that happened two months ago suggests Post traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). PTSD can develop after a traumatic event and involves symptoms such as re-experiencing the trauma (e.g., flashbacks, nightmares), avoidance of reminders of the trauma, negative alterations in mood and cognition, and increased arousal (e.g., irritability, difficulty sleeping).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute stress reaction: Acute stress reaction typically occurs immediately after a traumatic event and lasts for a few days to a few weeks.

 

Option B. Adjustment disorder: Adjustment disorder develops in response to a stressor and is characterized by emotional and behavioral symptoms, rather than the nightmares. It arises within three months of the stressor.

 

Option C. Mania: Mania is characterized by elevated mood, increased energy, and decreased need for sleep, among other symptoms, and isn't directly related to a traumatic event.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PTSD manifests after experiencing or witnessing significant traumatic event, with symptoms like flashbacks, nightmares,hypervigilance, exaggerated startle response,  severe anxiety centered on the event and avoidance of the situations that remind of the trauma. The symptoms must be present for at least one month. It is more common in females and young adults. Hippocampus and amygdala are implicated in the etiology of PTSD. Treatment includes trauma-focussed CBT (treatment of choice), SSRIs (Drug of choice), and eye movements desensitization and reprocessing.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 439-441.

questions.text: Which of the following is not classified as OCD as per ICD 11? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) PTSD

 

The International Classification of Diseases (ICD-11), like the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), classifies a number of disorders under the umbrella of obsessive-compulsive and related disorders. However, PTSD (Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder) is not classified as an obsessive-compulsive-related disorder in ICD-11. Instead, it's classified under trauma- and stressor-related disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichotillomania: This is classified as an obsessive-compulsive-related disorder in ICD-11.

 

Option B. Body dysmorphic disorder: This too is categorized as an obsessive-compulsive-related disorder in ICD-11.

 

Option C. Hypochondriac disorder: Now termed "Illness Anxiety Disorder" in DSM-5, this is categorized as an obsessive-compulsive-related disorder in ICD-11.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obsessive-compulsive or related disorders in ICD-11 are classified as:

 

  • Obsessive-compulsive disorder
  • Body dysmorphic disorder
  • Olfactory reference disorder
  • Hypochondriasis
  • Hoarding disorder
  • Trichotillomania
  • Excoriation disorder

 

Reference: International Classification of Diseases, 11th edition, Page No 43-47

questions.text: The serosa is an important tissue layer that forms part of the wall of several parts of the gastrointestinal tract. In which of the following parts of the GI tract is the serosa layer absent? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Esophagus

 

The esophagus does not have a serosa layer. Instead, it has an adventitia, a connective tissue layer that binds the esophagus to surrounding structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stomach: The stomach has a serosa layer, which is the outermost layer of the stomach wall. It is part of the visceral peritoneum that covers the stomach.

 

Option C. Small intestine: The small intestine, like most of the GI tract, has a serosa layer. This layer is continuous with the mesentery that helps attach the small intestine to the posterior abdominal wall.

 

Option D. Large intestine: The large intestine also has a serosa layer, which is part of the visceral peritoneum covering the intestine and is involved in forming the mesocolon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The esophagus is unique in the GI tract as it lacks a serosa layer and instead has an adventitia.

questions.text: The structure marked A in the image below gives rise to which of the following structures? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Falciform ligament

 

The structure marked A is ventral mesogastrium. The falciform ligament is a derivative of the ventral mesogastrium.

 

 

  • Mesogastriumis double layers of the peritoneum that enclose an organ (stomach) and connect it to the body wall. They provide pathways for vessels, nerves, and lymphatics to and from the abdominal viscera.
  • The ventral mesogastrium: is a structure found only in the foregut and is attached to the terminal part of the esophagus, the stomach, and the upper part of the duodenum.
  • It is derived from the septum transversum and is divided into two parts by the growth of the liver into the mesenchyme of the septum transversum.
  • These two parts are the lesser omentum, which extends from the lower portion of the esophagus, the stomach, and the upper portion of the duodenum to the liver, and the ligaments of the liver, which include all the liver ligaments except for the ligamentum teres.
  • The Dorsal mesogastrium: The foregut, midgut, and hindgut are connected to the posterior abdominal wall by the Dorsal mesogastrium.
  • The dorsal mesentery extends from the lower end of the esophagus to the cloacal region of the hindgut and has specific names depending on the region it is found in.
    • Dorsal mesogastrium (or greater omentum)- stomach
    • Dorsal mesoduodenum- duodenum
    • Mesentery proper- jejunum and ileum
    • Mesoappendix- appendix
    • Transverse mesocolon- transverse colon

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrosplenic Ligament: It is derived from the dorsal mesogastrium. It's a peritoneal fold that connects the greater curvature of the stomach to the spleen. The short gastric vessels and the left gastroepiploic vessels run within this ligament.

 

Option B. Lienorenal Ligament: It is also derived from the dorsal mesogastrium. This ligament connects the hilum of the spleen to the anterior surface of the left kidney. As with the gastrosplenic ligament, it's a reflection or fold of the peritoneum.

 

Option D. Gastrophrenic Ligament: it is derived from the dorsal mesogastrium. It is the portion of the greater omentum (which also has its origins in the dorsal mesogastrium) that attaches the stomach to the diaphragm. It's a reflection or fold of the peritoneum that connects the greater curvature of the stomach to the diaphragm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Falciform Ligament is derived from the ventral mesogastrium. This sickle-shaped ligament runs from the anterior abdominal wall to the liver, effectively connecting the liver to the diaphragm and anterior abdominal wall. The ligamentum teres (remnant of the umbilical vein) runs within the free edge of this ligament.

choices.text: It’s administered on the anterolateral aspect of thigh
A prior adverse reaction with temperature above 37 degrees is a contraindication
Cellular pertussis component in the vaccine is not recommended after 7-years of age
The diphtheria toxoid dose in adults is much lesser than the pediatric dose

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy experienced symptoms of a sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and a slight fever. Upon examination, the presented clinical image is visible. Which of the following sentences is false regarding the vaccine that could have prevented this condition? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) A prior adverse reaction with temperature above 37 degrees is a contraindication

 

A prior adverse reaction with temperature above 37 degrees is a contraindication: This is false. A prior adverse reaction with a temperature above 40 degrees Celsius is a contraindication, not 37 degrees Celsius. Minor reactions, such as a mild fever, are not typically considered a contraindication for future vaccinations.

 

Other Options:  

 

Option A.  It’s administered on the anterolateral aspect of thigh: This is true. The DPT vaccine is typically administered intramuscularly on the anterolateral aspect of the thigh in infants and young children.

 

Option C. Cellular pertussis component in the vaccine is not recommended after 7-years of age: This is true. The whole-cell pertussis vaccine is generally not recommended for individuals over the age of 7 due to an increased risk of adverse reactions. Instead, the acellular pertussis vaccine is used in older children and adults.

 

Option D. The diphtheria toxoid dose in adults is much lesser than the pediatric dose: This is true. The diphtheria toxoid dose in adults is lower than in pediatric formulations to reduce the risk of adverse reactions while still providing adequate immunity.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents to the emergency department with intermittent episodes of severe colicky abdominal pain, vomiting, and passage of currant jelly stools. The clinical suspicion is towards intussusception. Taking the child's immunization history, which recent vaccine could be associated with a slightly increased risk of this condition? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Rotavirus vaccine

 

Rotavirus vaccine is associated with a complication of intussusception.

 

ROTA virus vaccines

 

  • 4 Types – but 2 used in NIS
  • ROTAVAC and ROTASIL (live, att., lyophilized with diluent citrate bicarbonate buffer)
  • ROTAVAC →1 dose = 0.5 ml
  • ROTASIIL → 1 dose – 2.5 ml with 6 ml syringe
  • 3 doses – 6, 10, 14 weeks
  • Complication - INTUSSUSCEPTION

 

 

 

Other 3 Options: Not associated with intussusception.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rotavirus vaccine is associated with a rare complication of intussusception, an important consideration when assessing an infant presenting with symptoms of this condition.

questions.text: A defect in which of the following forms the structure marked below as A? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Fascia transversalis

 

Marked structure is the deep inguinal ring, formed by a defect in fascia transversalis.

 

The deep inguinal ring is an opening in the transversalis fascia present 1 cm above the inguinal ligament, midway between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic symphysis.

 

An indirect inguinal hernia arises through the deep inguinal ring, lateral to the inferior epigastric vessel.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Internal Oblique:  The internal oblique muscle is one of the three major muscles of the lateral abdominal wall. It lies just deep to the external oblique and superficial to the transversus abdominis.

 

  • Origin and Insertion: It originates from the lumbar fascia, anterior two-thirds of the iliac crest, and lateral half of the inguinal ligament. It inserts into the lower ribs, linea alba, and the pubic bone.
  • Innervation: It is innervated by the lower six thoracoabdominal nerves and the first lumbar nerve.

 

Option B. External Oblique: The external oblique is the most superficial of the three flat muscles of the lateral abdominal wall.

 

  • Origin and Insertion: It originates from the outer surfaces of the 5th to 12th ribs and inserts into the linea alba, pubic tubercle, and anterior half of the iliac crest.
  • Innervation: Like the internal oblique, it's innervated by the lower six thoracoabdominal nerves and the first lumbar nerve.

 

Option C. Parietal Peritoneum: The parietal peritoneum is the outer layer of the peritoneum that lines the internal surface of the abdominal wall.

 

  • Composition: It consists of a single layer of squamous epithelial cells (mesothelium) and its underlying connective tissue.
  • Innervation: The parietal peritoneum overlying the anterior abdominal wall is primarily innervated by the lower six thoracoabdominal nerves and the first lumbar nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fascia Transversalis: The fascia transversalis is a thin aponeurotic membrane which lies between the inner surface of the transversus abdominis muscle and the parietal peritoneum. It covers the entire inner surface of the abdominal wall and is continuous with the iliac and pelvic fasciae.

 

Hernias that penetrate the fascia transversalis in the groin region are called direct inguinal hernias.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a type of subcortical dementia?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pick's disease

 

To approach this question, we need to differentiate between cortical and subcortical dementias.

 

This is a type of frontotemporal dementia and is cortical. It primarily affects the frontal and temporal lobes. Memory may be preserved in the early stages, but personality and language changes are prominent. Therefore, it doesn't fall under the subcortical category, making it the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Parkinson's disease: Parkinson's primarily affects the basal ganglia in the brain, which is a subcortical structure. The primary symptoms are motoric (tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia), but dementia can develop in the later stages of the disease.

 

Option C. Huntington's disease: This is a genetic disorder that affects the basal ganglia, especially the caudate nucleus, which is also a subcortical structure. Cognitive decline and psychiatric symptoms are common.

 

Option D. Wilson's disease: This is a genetic disorder that leads to copper accumulation in the body, including the brain. The basal ganglia is one of the primary areas affected, making the dementia subcortical in nature.

 

Given the options, Pick's disease is the only cortical dementia, making it the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 24.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used as an anti-smoking agent? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Varenicline

 

Varenicline is an FDA-approved medication that helps individuals quit smoking by reducing the craving and withdrawal symptoms associated with tobacco use. It acts as a partial agonist at alpha4 beta2 nicotinic acetylcholine receptors, which can both stimulate the receptor (to reduce craving) and block nicotine from binding (to reduce the rewarding effects of cigarettes).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Busulfan: An alkylating agent used primarily in the treatment of chronic myelogenous leukemia.

 

Option B. Acamprosate: Used to treat alcohol dependence by reducing the craving for alcohol.

 

Option D. Gabapentin: An anticonvulsant that is also used for neuropathic pain and certain mood disorders.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Varenicline is a partial agonist at α4β2 & α7 nicotinic acetylcholine receptors. As a partial agonist it prevents high and reinforcement and also controls craving and withdrawal due to tobacco use. It is the most effective agent for tobacco use disorders.

 

Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 505.
